para.paratext: The doctrine of merger or integration is one of the basic principles regarding parol evidence: when parties reduce their entire agreement to writing, all oral or written negotiations preceding or contemporaneous therewith are merged into, terminated, and extinguished by the writing. Having been merged into the final writing, the extrinsic evidence is not admissible to contradict or vary the terms of the writing. The doctrine of merger has been stated many times in Georgia.[1]

The intent of the parties is the major consideration when applying the doctrine of merger. There are some exceptions to this doctrine. For example, the merger clause did not apply to negotiations between a parent company and an employee of a subsidiary where the employment agreement only referenced the agreement between the employee and the subsidiary.[2]

Extrinsic or parol contemporaneous evidence is inadmissible to contradict or vary the terms of a valid written instrument. Generally, the term “instruments” refers only to those written legal documents that define rights, duties, entitlements, or liabilities, such as a contract, will, promissory note, or share certificate. An invoice for goods delivered on open account is not a “valid written instrument” as that term is used for the parol evidence rule.[3] A typical example of “a valid written instrument” is the written contract of vendor and purchaser is the deed in a sale of realty.[4]
The merger doctrine also may, in some circumstances, be disregarded in criminal cases.[5]

E.g., Logan v. Bond, 13 Ga. 192, 1853 WL 1574 (1853); Smith v. Newton, 59 Ga. 113, 1877 WL 3143 (1877); Thompson v. Arrington, 209 Ga. 343, 72 S.E.2d 293 (1952); Simpson v. Tate, 226 Ga. 558, 176 S.E.2d 62 (1970); Fabian v. Pontikakis, 327 Ga. App. 392, 759 S.E.2d 295 (2014).
HA & W Financial Advisors, LLC v. Johnson, 336 Ga. App. 647, 782 S.E.2d 855 (2016).
Wheeler v. IDN-Armstrong's, Inc., 288 Ga. App. 253, 653 S.E.2d 835 (2007).
Willingham v. Anderson, 90 Ga. App. 799, 84 S.E.2d 471 (1954).
Davis v. State, 326 Ga. App. 279, 754 S.E.2d 815 (2014).
